DOC.HEAD: Combat Christmas in Panama: Glad to Be Alive
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Though the Christmas trees and bright faces of loved ones may have been missing, the 26,000 U.S. soldiers occupying Panama on Christmas Day had a lot to be thankful for: they were alive. A few even managed to gloat. ``I was freezing to death on Pope Air Force Base (in North Carolina) five days ago,'' one said at the former home of the ousted Panamanian strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``Now I'm eating off Noriega's china.'' However, 21-year-old Sgt. Ernie Nieto, said, ``I'm just glad to see Christmas. The other night (in combat) I just wanted to see sunup.'' He spoke at the fire-blackened ruins of Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters, destroyed in the early hours of the invasion. Nieto's tour of duty in Panama was up the day before the United States invaded Dec. 20, and he had planned on a Christmas at home in Albuquerque, N.M. Instead, he was in a gutted building. At the home of Noriega, two squads from the 82nd Airborne Division munched the modern version of K-rations a few yards from the deposed dictator's lavish Christmas tree. For the men on guard at the gate, there were soft drinks and cheers from Noriega's neighbors. ``Do you need anything? Do you want some ice?'' Ana Julia Real asked as she handed four quart bottles of Coca-Cola over the high stone wall. ``Merry Christmas!'' a man called as he passed. E4 Greg Frye of Daltona, Fla., passed the sodas around to the rest of his squad, sweating in the tropical heat. ``I try not to think about Christmas because that just makes it harder,'' he said. ``But the moral support of the people has really helped.'' Sgt. John Stowe was one of the few who had planned to spend Christmas in Panama City. But he thought it would be his hometown, Panama City, Fla. Instead of unwrapping Christmas gifts, he was cracking open boxes of G3 assault rifles at an arms cache. He didn't seem to mind. The cache was one of the biggest found so far. At the international airport, which U.S. troops seized the first night of the invasion, a group of soldiers sat around with their M-16s singing Christmas carols. For some, it was still a family Christmas, even though they were far from home. Sgt. 1st Class William Lucas and his son, Pvt. William Lucas Jr., both parachuted in with the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C. So did Lt. William Knowlton and his brother, 2nd Lt. Mark Knowlton, of Fayetteville, N.C. Marine Corp. Chris Moeller, 20, managed to get someone to call his wife, Jamie, and his 2-year-old son, Matthew, with this message: ``Tell her I love her very much and to have a very merry Christmas.'' Mrs. Moeller, in Martin, Tenn., wept when she got the call. ``One guy he knows was killed and another was wounded,'' she said. ``I have been so worried.'' The corporal's presents are wrapped and waiting for him when he gets home, she said.
